<!-- Layout -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Courses for Fall 2017</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								<div class="content">



		<div class="course-section" id="PHIL">
			
				<ul class="course-list">
										<li id="PHIL0030">
					<h4>Skepticism and Knowledge</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">What is knowledge?  What is the extent and basis of one's knowledge about physical objects, other people, oneself, the future, morality, and religion? WRIT </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/philosophy/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=15422">PHIL 0030 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Ackerman</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="PHIL0050">
					<h4>Aesthetics: Art and Morality</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">From Plato to the present, the power of the arts to trigger powerful emotions has been seen by some thinkers as a threat to morality, by others as a vital support.  This debate raises such issues as whether aesthetic experience is a distinctive kind of experience and whether the creation and reception of art are autonomous activities free from the constraints of morality and politics.  Beyond Plato, authors to be read will include such figures as Hume, Mendelssohn, Rousseau, Kant, Schiller, Hegel, Schopenhauer, Ruskin, Tolstoy, Collingwood, Stanley Cavell, Martha Nussbaum, Alexander Nehamas, and others. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/philosophy/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=16546">PHIL 0050 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Guyer</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="PHIL0260">
					<h4>Philosophy of Social Science</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">This is a general introduction to the philosophy of social science. Social science brings with it certain specific problems and modes of explanation. This course is designed to introduce students to some of the issues surrounding social science. What sorts of problems and phenomena are social scientists concerned with explaining? How are they different from the problems tackled by natural scientists? Is there a mode of explanation distinctive of social science? What sorts of theoretical tools do social scientists use? We'll consider all these questions, and more. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/philosophy/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=17508">PHIL 0260 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Sankaran</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="PHIL0300G">
					<h4>Introduction to the Philosophy of Wittgenstein </h4>
					<div class="course-overview">This course examines Wittgenstein’s two groundbreaking works, the Tractatus Logico-Philosophicus (1921) and the Philosophical Investigations (1953), both of which reshaped 20th-century thought. What are the limits of language? What is the nature of philosophy? Can there be such a thing as a private language? Wittgenstein addresses these and other questions in both works. His answers are at times cryptic, such as when he says “The limits of language mean the limits of my world”. The primary goal of this course is to come to grips with the main claims of both works and the development of Wittgenstein’s thought. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/philosophy/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=17566">PHIL 0300G S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Moore</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="PHIL0350">
					<h4>Ancient Philosophy</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">This course will introduce students to the major concerns of Greek philosophy, and how they are addressed by the Presocratics, Plato, Aristotle, and the Stoics. We will have two related ends: historical and critical. On the one hand, we will get clear so far as we are able what it is that these thinkers thought; on the other, it is important to evaluate their arguments. This course will emphasize the identification of the problems and the solutions to them that seemed pressing to these thinkers, especially if such problems seem alien to us. WRIT </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/philosophy/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=15454">PHIL 0350 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Laidley</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="PHIL0540">
					<h4>Logic</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">An introduction to perhaps the most fundamental tool of rational thought: deductive logic. Course begins with basic sentential logic, then moves on to deduction, quantification, and predication. Argumentation and reasoning may also be addressed at times. No previous experience with logic or philosophy is required. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/philosophy/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=15455">PHIL 0540 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Heck</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="PHIL0850">
					<h4>Introduction to the Philosophy of Language</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">Discussion of the nature of linguistic meaning and other topics, such as vagueness; metaphor; and language, thought, and culture. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/philosophy/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=15432">PHIL 0850 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Bjurman Pautz</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="PHIL0990F">
					<h4>Perception</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">Begins with a reading of some classic works, and then moves on to contemporary work. Topics include: naive realist versus representational theories of sensory experience, the possibility that sensory experience is massively illusory (so that we already occupy a kind of “virtual reality”), the role of the brain in shaping sensory experience, and the alleged foundational role of sensory experience in knowledge. The focus will be on vision but we will also discuss other sense-modalities </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/philosophy/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=15456">PHIL 0990F S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Pautz</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="PHIL0990T">
					<h4>Paradox and Infinity</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">This course will focus on several important paradoxes that arise within philosophy and mathematics. We will use these paradoxes to investigate central issues in metaphysics, the philosophy of language, decision theory, physics, mathematics, and logic. Among the paradoxes we will discuss are Zeno's paradoxes of space, time, and motion; the paradoxes of set theory; the paradoxes of truth and reference; the sorites paradox; and paradoxes of rational action and rational belief. Enrollment limited to 20. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/philosophy/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=16400">PHIL 0990T S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Schechter</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="PHIL0991L">
					<h4>Scepticism, Ancient and Modern: Sextus, Descartes, Hume</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">Ancient Sceptics had a great series of arguments for undermining claims to knowledge and (some say) belief. (Honey tastes sweet to some, but bitter to people with a fever. 'Since everything is relative, we shall suspend judgement as to how things are independently'. And many more.) But, some say, it was only with Descartes that philosophers put in question the very existence of an independent world. We shall explore what kind of life the life of a sceptic may be; what kinds of fragmentation of the world may (or may not) result; and some differences between older and newer forms of scepticism. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/philosophy/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=15620">PHIL 0991L S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Broackes</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="PHIL1400">
					<h4>Ethics in the Novel</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">Consideration of novels in terms of their treatment of such philosophical themes as death, courage, faith, betrayal, responsibility to others, and mercy. Focuses on themes in moral philosophy rather than themes in social and political philosophy. The course deals with contemporary American novels and also with Malory. No pre-requisites. WRIT </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/philosophy/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=15425">PHIL 1400 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Ackerman</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="PHIL1520">
					<h4>Consciousness</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">Topics will include: (i) the different features of various types of consciousness; (ii) dualist, physicalist, and representationalist theories of experience; (iii) the nature of pain and other bodily sensations; (iv) the nature of conscious thought; (v) the qualitative dimension of perception; (vi) introspection; (vii) the roles of attention and working memory in perceptual consciousness; (viii) blindsight, inattentional blindness, hemineglect, and related phenomena; (ix) the unconscious; and (x) what it is for a state of consciousness to be unified. WRIT </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/philosophy/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=16547">PHIL 1520 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Hill</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="PHIL1590">
					<h4>Philosophy of Science</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">Some very general, basic questions concerning science.  Can evidence justify belief in theories which go beyond the evidence?  What is the nature of good scientific reasoning?  Is there a single scientific method? What is a scientific explanation?  Does science reveal truths about unobservable reality, or merely tell us about parts of the world we can measure directly? WRIT </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/philosophy/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=15511">PHIL 1590 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Christensen</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="PHIL1650">
					<h4>Moral Theories</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">A systematic examination of the main alternative normative moral theories: consequentialism; moral rights; moral duties; moral virtues. Focuses on the principal issues in the formulation of the different theories, on the main points of conflict between them, and on the critical evaluation of each. Readings are drawn mainly from contemporary work in moral philosophy. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/philosophy/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=15426">PHIL 1650 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Arpaly</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="PHIL1750">
					<h4>Epistemology</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">We’ll concentrate on several issues involving knowledge and rational belief:  What is knowledge, and how does it relate to rational or justified belief?  Does a person’s knowing something depend on non-evidential factors such as the practical importance of the person’s being correct?  Does the justification of a person’s belief depend just on facts internal to the person—or might it depend on her environment?  And what can we learn from thinking about the skeptical position which claims that we’re not justified in believing even the most ordinary things about the world around us? WRIT </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/philosophy/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=15510">PHIL 1750 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Christensen</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>

				</li>
										<li id="PHIL2020P">
					<h4>Color and its Place in Nature</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">Focuses on the nature and status of color, an instance of the ancient puzzle of appearance vs. reality. We will begin by examining contemporary realist views of color (Armstrong, Byrne and Hilbert, Tye). Then we will take a look at irrealist approaches (Chalmers, Pautz). Finally we will look at “relativist views” (Jonathan Cohen, Jack Spencer). Although the focus will be on color, we will also sometimes discuss other sensible properties (audible qualities, olfactory qualities, etc.) </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/philosophy/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=15622">PHIL 2020P S01</a></h5>
															<div class="section-text">This course is held on MIT's campus in Boston, MA.  Building 32, room D831.</div>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Pautz</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="PHIL2030A">
					<h4>Moral Psychology</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">This seminar will examine in depth some problems associated with morality, rationality, and the human psyche. Possible topics: acting for reasons, moral responsibility,  practical reasoning, moral character, love, modesty, being too good, moral luck, desire, weakness of will. Undergraduates require instructor permission to enroll. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/philosophy/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=15844">PHIL 2030A S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Arpaly</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="PHIL2150I">
					<h4>Plato's Theaetetus</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">In this seminar, we will discuss Plato's Theaetetus, his investigation of knowledge, and associated topics, including relativism, perception, true and false judgment, and accounts, with a view to understanding how Plato distinguishes knowledge from true belief. Open to graduate students only; others may enroll with instructor permission. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/philosophy/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=15846">PHIL 2150I S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Gill</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="PHIL2200">
					<h4>Graduate Proseminar</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">Will cover classics of philosophy from the end of the 19th century to the end of the 20th; including ethics as well as metaphysics, epistemology and philosophy of language. </div>

						</div>

					<h4>Thesis Preparation</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">For graduate students who have met the tuition requirement and are paying the registration fee to continue active enrollment while preparing a thesis. </div>

										<li id="PHILXLIST">
					<h4>Courses of Interest to Philosophy Concentrators</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">There are many courses that look at philosophers or philosophical questions in other departments, including Africana Studies, Classics, Cognitive and Linguistic Sciences, French Studies, German Studies, Judaic Studies, Mathematics, Modern Culture and Media, Political Science, and Religious Studies.  They include:<br>
<b>Classics</b><br>
CLAS 1140 Classical Philosophy of India<br> </div>

	</div> <!-- end .course-section -->



</div>



<script type="text/javascript">
	// @todo: make show/hide link dynamically generated
	$(document).ready(function(){
	
		$(".course-list .additional-sections").hide();

		// add additional sections toggle link
		$(".course-list .additional-sections").each(function(i,el){
			var numSections = $(".section", $(this)).length;
			numSections = (numSections == 1) ? numSections + " additional section" : numSections + " additional sections";
			var anchor = $(this).parents("li").attr('id');
			$(this).after('<span class="section-count">[<a href="#' + anchor + '">Show ' + numSections + '</a>]</span>');
		});

		// now add the show/hide event listeners		
		$(".section-count").each(function(i,el){
			$("a", this).bind("click keypress", function(){
				$(".additional-sections", $(this).parents("li")).slideToggle("fast");
				window.location.hash = $(this).attr("href");
				if($(this).html().match(/Show/)) {
					$(this).html($(this).html().replace("Show", "Hide"));
				} else if($(this).html().match(/Hide/)) {
					$(this).html($(this).html().replace("Hide", "Show"));
				}
				this.text(($('#toggle').text() == 'Show more') ? 'Show less' : 'Show more');
				return false;
			});
		});
		
		if (window.location.hash) {
			var hash = window.location.hash;
			if(hash.match(/#[0-9]{4}/)) {
				$(hash +  " .additional-sections").slideDown("fast");
				$(hash +  " a[href='"+hash+"']").html($(hash +  " a[href='"+hash+"']").html().replace("Show", "Hide"));
			}
		}

	});
</script>
							</div>

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Graduate</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
<article id="node-13" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <h2>Brown University Ph.D. Program in Philosophy</h2>
<p>Brown University Ph. D. program in Philosophy is designed to provide strong support for students’ research. After devoting two years to coursework, students begin their research in the third year by conducting literature reviews under the supervision of faculty members, and by enrolling in a seminar that is intended to promote work aimed at publication. These special courses help students to identify dissertation topics. Dissertation work begins in earnest in the fourth year. In that year and in succeeding years, students enroll every semester in a special seminar, the dissertation workshop, in which they present their research and receive feedback from faculty and peers. During this time they also work closely with dissertation advisers other members of their dissertation committees.</p>
<p><span>Financial support is guaranteed for the first five years of study, and also for the first four summers. It is not guaranteed for the sixth year, but in almost all cases thus far, applications for sixth year support have been successful. In the first year, students focus exclusively on course work. Teaching responsibilities begin in the second year, continue through the fourth year, and return in the sixth year. In the fifth year, however, students set teaching aside so they can concentrate on dissertation research. In this year, they may, if they like, spend periods of time at other universities, interacting with faculty and students who share their interests. Teaching responsibilities generally take the form of work as assistants in courses run by faculty, but in the fourth and sixth years, students may apply to be teaching fellows, in which case they have full responsibility for undergraduate courses. There are also opportunities for summer teaching.</span></p>
<p><span>The Department has several endowed funds, designed to support the development of graduate students and generally to improve the intellectual environment of the graduate program. The Graduate Professional Development Fund is used exclusively to promote graduate scholarship. Among other things, it provides support for giving talks at conferences and for travel to take courses at other institutions. The Mark Shapiro Fund supports an annual conference that is run entirely by graduate students. This fund also supports a bi-annual academic conference in a specific topic and a lecture series. The Royce Lectureship Fund supports a prestigious lecture series in philosophy of mind, and our department sponsors a further lecture series in collaboration with Blackwell Publishing. Finally, the Chisholm Fund currently supports a bi-annual Distinguished Visitor series, which brings to our department a distinguished philosopher for one semester. The department is also home to independently funded academic programs that sponsor multiple activities, such as lectures, workshops, and conferences in specific areas of philosophy, including the <em><a href="http://brown.edu/academics/philosophy/ethical-inquiry/" target="_blank">Program for Ethical Inquiry</a></em> and the <em><a href="http://www.brown.edu/Research/ppw/" target="_blank">Political Philosophy Workshop</a></em>.</span></p>
<p>&nbsp;<span>In addition to these departmental funds, the Brown Graduate School also makes substantial awards in support of travel by graduate students. Moreover, the Open Masters Program allows students to apply to pursue an MA degree in another discipline while pursuing a Ph. D. in Philosophy. Students admitted in this program automatically receive an additional year of financial support to complete their MA degree. Students may also apply for extra support from the University’s <em><a href="http://www.brown.edu/academics/humanities/" target="_blank">Cogut Humanities Center</a></em>. Finally, they can receive substantial assistance with teaching at the <em><a href="http://www.brown.edu/about/administration/sheridan-center/" target="_blank">Sheridan Center for Teaching and Learning. &nbsp;&nbsp;</a></em></span></p>
<p><a href="http://www.stg.brown.edu/projects/gradschool/admission.html" target="_blank">Apply Online</a></p>
<p>The Department offers admission in the fall only for its Ph.D. program. (Please note that there is no separate M.A. program in philosophy.<sup>1</sup>) Application may be made&nbsp;<a href="http://www.stg.brown.edu/projects/gradschool/admission.html" target="_blank">online</a>. Applicants must submit official transcripts, three letters of recommendation, official GRE scores (no advanced subject test is required), and a sample of philosophical writing. The application deadline is 2 January.</p>
<p>The preliminary requirements for the Ph.D. are satisfied by demonstrating competence in logic, philosophy of science, language, and mind, ethics, epistemology, metaphysics, and history of philosophy. This may be done either by passing prescribed courses with a quality grade or through satisfactory completion of an individually tailored major-minors program, planned in consultation with the Director of Graduate Studies and submitted to the department for approval.</p>
<p>Within seven semesters of full-time or equivalent residency at Brown, the student must gain admission to Ph.D. candidacy. Admission to candidacy is granted after satisfaction of the preliminary evaluation and distribution requirements and upon approval of a dissertation prospectus by a dissertation committee. An oral defense of the dissertation is required once it is completed.</p>
<p>Information about graduate studies in philosophy at Brown University is available in the department's<a href="https://www.brown.edu/academics/philosophy/sites/brown.edu.academics.philosophy/files/uploads/Graduate%20Handbook%20%282017%20version%29.pdf" target="_blank"> Graduate Student Handbook</a>.</p>
<p>Inquiries regarding&nbsp;<strong>graduate admissions</strong>&nbsp;should be directed to the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.brown.edu/academics/gradschool/" target="_blank">Graduate School</a>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<em>not</em>&nbsp;to the Director of Graduate Studies. The Director of Graduate Studies is responsible only for the Graduate Program, and plays no role in the admissions process.</p>
<hr />
<div class="footnote">
<p><sup>1</sup>This is not to say that the department does not offer a Master of Arts degree. Any student who has completed the preliminary requirements for the Ph.D. is eligible to be awarded an M.A. It is sometimes taken as a terminal degree by those who decide, for whatever reason, not to complete the Ph.D., but who have completed the preliminary requirements. And it is sometimes taken as a non-terminal degree by students who do intend to complete the Ph.D. but who would just like to receive it. The degree may also be awarded to Brown undergraduates admitted to the A.B./A.M. program.&nbsp;</p>
</div>
<fieldset class="fieldgroup group-related-files"><legend>Related Files</legend><div class="field field-type-filefield field-field-related-files">

  <div class="content">
        <h2>Graduate Students</h2>
<p><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/philosophy/sites/brown.edu.academics.philosophy/files/images/Barnett.jpg" alt="Zach Barnett" title="Zach Barnett"  class="image image-_original " width="100" height="125" /><span class="caption"><strong>Zach Barnett</strong></span></span><a href="mailto:Zachary_Barnett@brown.edu" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Zachary_Barnett@brown.edu</a> <br /><a href="https://sites.google.com/view/zachbarnett" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Visit Zach on the web</a></p>

		<div class="wrapper">
		
			<header id="header-region">
				<section id="audience-gateways">
					<div class="marginator">
						<h6>Information For:</h6> 
						<ul>

<!-- Layout -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Undergraduate</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
<article id="node-12" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <h2><span>Description</span></h2>
<p>The undergraduate concentration in philosophy offers courses covering all of the main areas of the discipline, from epistemology and metaphysics to philosophy of religion, philosophy of literature, and feminist philosophy. It also offers courses covering all the various periods in the  history of philosophy. Concentrators can expect to strengthen their  knowledge of and skills in ancient philosophy, early modern philosophy,  logic, epistemology, metaphysics and philosophy of value. While the concentration provides a strong general education in philosophy, concentrators are required to identify  an area of specialization.</p>
<p>Students with questions about the concentration should contact the Director of Undergraduate Studies, <a href="mailto:justin_broackes@brown.edu" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Justin Broackes</a>.</p>
<h2>Student Goals</h2>
<p>Students in philosophy will:</p>
<ul>
<li>Learn to think analytically and creatively about philosophical texts and issues</li>
<li>Understand the work of major figures in the history of philosophy, including Plato, Aristotle, Descartes and Kant</li>
<li>Become familiar with arguments and approaches in metaphysics or  epistemology, and a selection of other areas of philosophy, such as  philosophy of mind and philosophy of language; as well as topics in  ethics and political philosophy</li>
<li>Know how to carry out logical proofs and derivations within a formal system</li>
<li>Produce a significant body of written work</li>
</ul>
<h2>Concentration Requirements</h2>
<p>New concentration requirements became effective in January 2013.  Students who declared their concentration prior to that date are still  subject to the old requirements, which can be found in the <a href="http://bulletin.brown.edu/the-college/concentrations/phil/" target="_blank">University Bulletin</a>.</p>
<p>The current requirement is ten courses total of which no more than  one may be below Phil 0350, and at least three of which must be at or  above Phil 0990.</p>
<h3>Distribution Requirements</h3>
<p>Each philosophy concentrator must take:</p>
<ul>
<li>One course in Ancient Philosophy<br />e.g. Phil 0350 Ancient Philosophy; Phil 1250 Aristotle	; Phil 1260 Plato; Phil 1310 Myth and the Origins of Science</li>
<li>One course in Early Modern Philosophy<br />e.g. Phil 0360 Early Modern Philosophy; Phil 1700 British  Empiricists; Phil 1710 17th Century Continental Rationalism; Phil 1720 Kant: The Critique of Pure Reason</li>
<li>One course in Epistemology or Metaphysics<br />e.g. Phil 1660 Metaphysics; Phil 1750 Epistemology; Phil 1760 Philosophy of Language; Phil 1765 Sense and Reference; Phil 1770 Philosophy of Mind</li>
<li>One course in Ethics or Political Philosophy<br />e.g. Phil 0500 Moral Philosophy; Phil 0560 Political Philosophy;  Phil 1640 The Nature of Morality; Phil 1650 &nbsp;Moral Theories</li>
<li>One course in Logic<br />e.g. Phil 0540 Logic; Phil 1630 Deductive Logic; Phil 1880 Advanced Deductive Logic; Phil 1885 Incompleteness</li>
<li>One seminar: &nbsp;A course from the Phil 0990 series or any seminar at the 2000-level, which may be counted for one of the other requirements.</li>
</ul>
<h3>Specialization</h3>
<p>Students are asked to choose a "specialization", consisting of three  related courses from a single area of philosophy, for example: logic and  language; philosophy of science; epistemology; philosophy of mind; moral  philosophy; political philosophy; ancient philosophy; and so forth. At  most one course from the specialization can also be counted for one of  the five area requirements.</p>
<p>Concentrators who aim at a general acquaintance with the discipline of philosophy may forgo a specialization and devise an appropriately balanced program of courses beyond the requirements with the approval of the DUS (Director of Undergraduate Studies).</p>
<p>No more than one course may fulfill both a general distribution requirement and a specialization requirement.</p>
<p>No more than two courses from departments other than the philosophy department may be counted among the ten courses required for the concentration; no more than one of these two outside courses may count towards the three specialization requirements.&nbsp;</p>
<p>The specialization and the courses that will fulfill it are standardly declared at some point in the course of the Junior year. &nbsp;Those making a Concentration Declaration at an earlier time (e.g. at the end of their Sophomore year) may make a provisional choice of courses which can be revised at a later date with the approval of the department's DUS (Director of Undergraduate Studies).</p>
<ul class="small">
</ul>
<h5>Capstone</h5>
<p>Each philosophy concentrator must complete a "capstone". For more information, see the page on the <a href="http://www.brown.edu/academics/philosophy/undergraduate/senior-year" target="_blank">senior year</a>.</p>
<h2>Honors</h2>
<p>Philosophy concentrators have the option of writing an <a href="http://www.brown.edu/academics/philosophy/undergraduate/thesis" target="_blank">Honor's Thesis</a>,  which is typically researched and written over the course of the entire  senior year. Interested students should consult with the concentration  advisor during the sixth semester concerning procedures and  requirements. &nbsp;Philosophy GPA must be greater than 3.5. &nbsp;(This refers to the GPA at the beginning of the senior year in all philosophy courses, and including at least six courses.)</p>
<h2>Physics and Philosophy Concentration</h2>
<p>This page describes the "standard" concentration in Philosophy. There is  also a related but separate concentration in Physics and Philosophy.  More information on that program is available from  <a href="http://brown.edu/academics/physics/undergraduate/concentrations/concentrations" target="_blank">the Physics department</a> and from  <a href="http://www.brown.edu/Administration/Registrar/Concentrations-70b.htm" target="_blank">the Registrar's office</a>.</p>
  </div>

	



  <div class="clear-block">
    <div class="meta">

			
	    
		</div><!-- end .meta -->
	</div>

</article>
							</div>

					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Senior Year </h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
<article id="node-313" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <h2>Senior Year Options</h2>
<p>There are several options for a 'Capstone Experience' in philosophy.</p>
<h3>An Honors Thesis</h3>
<p>Seniors wishing to earn honors by presenting a senior honors thesis should consult their concentration advisor during their sixth semester or at the start of the seventh semester, concerning procedures and requirements. In addition to completing the usual nonhonors requirements, a student must write a thesis judged to be of honors quality by two readers and have a grade point average of over 3.5 in philosophy courses. &nbsp;(The GPA at the beginning of the senior year must be greater than 3.5, including at least six courses, of which at least five must be taken for a letter grade; and the GPA must be at least 3.5 at the end of the Senior year.) Honors theses are usually prepared over two semesters' work with an advisor. There is more information on writing an honors thesis on&nbsp;<a href="http://www.brown.edu/academics/philosophy/undergraduate/thesis" target="_blank">this page.</a></p>
<h3>A Reading Course</h3>
<p>Many professors will be happy to set up a Phil 1990 reading course for one semester with an individual student, e.g. leading to the preparation of a special large paper on a particular topic of research. One option is to set up a Reading Course to accompany a 1000-level course that you have recently taken or are taking at the same time. For example, you might take Phil 1660 Metaphysics, and also do a special reading course on Necessity or on Reduction and Supervenience. Or you might take Phil 1640, The Nature of Morality, and also do a reading course to specialize in the notion of Moral Facts. In each case the 1000-level course would provide a general overview of the topic and give you an idea of one professor's views, and then you could research further in the subject either with that same professor or with another with overlapping interests. A one-semester Reading Course may also for some people be a first step towards writing an Honors Thesis.</p>
<h3>Senior Seminars</h3>
<p><span>There are seminars in the Phil 0990 series, aimed primarily at advanced undergraduates, on varying topics each year.</span></p>
<h3>Graduate Seminars</h3>
<p>2000-level seminars are mainly aimed at graduate students, but many are able to take advanced undergraduates as well. The best preparation is usually to have done a 1000-level course with the same professor or in the same general area of philosophy.</p>
<p><span>Please feel free to talk to the Concentration Advisors about ideas and questions you might have about any of these options or to approach in office hours individual professors who might be able to help you as an advisor for a particular project.</span></p>
  </div>

	



  <div class="clear-block">

				<div id="content">

					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Thesis</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
<article id="node-314" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <h2>Senior Thesis</h2>
<p>There is no requirement for people concentrating in Philosophy to write an Undergraduate Honors Thesis; some people do so, many people don't.</p>
<p>To write a thesis, you need a topic and an Advisor and a suitable amount of time. There is no single model to follow, but one standard approach is this. You'd work on the thesis during the two semesters of your Senior Year. In the first semester, you might work through a reading program with the advice of your Advisor, meeting with her or him three or four times in the semester and writing two or three pieces of work—for example, discussions of existing publications in the field and sketches of your own responses to them. Over the break you'd pull together a plan for the thesis itself. In the second semester, you'd write a first draft of the thesis and then a final draft—expecting, of course, that you would continue to do some new reading, and that you might need to be flexible with your original plan. The thesis itself is due about April 15th (or more exactly, two weeks before the Friday on which the Reading Period begins).</p>
<h3>Thesis Topic</h3>
<p>It is possible in principle to choose a topic which you don't know much about in advance; but typically the result of that is that you have to spend a larger amount of time reaching base camp, so to speak—getting a decent grasp of existing approaches to the topic—and you have less time for heading up to the summit—developing ideas of your own. Many of the best theses come when a student has already got some idea of a problem area, e.g. from a 1000 level course that might have spent a week or two on the detailed topic in question, and might have introduced the class to materials and methods used in related areas that might constitute a useful tool-kit for this topic too. If you already know a bit about the existing approaches to the topic, but have a feeling that you're not quite satisfied with any of them, then you're probably in a good position to go deeper into it, researching further proposals from other people and working out a distinctive contribution of your own.</p>
<h3>Advisor</h3>
<p>When you have a first idea of the area in which you'd like to work, you can approach a potential advisor direct, e.g. by e-mail or in Office Hours, or you can discuss the matter with your Concentration Advisor, who should be able to point you towards Faculty Members with interests in areas close to your proposed topic. Don't let your ideas become too fixed too early: often a good discussion will leave you thinking of unexpected directions you'll want to head off in. The normal time for approaching an Advisor is in the first week of the first semester of your Senior Year (or a few days earlier), or at the end of the last semester of the Junior Year.</p>
<h3>Course Registrations</h3>
<p>The standard thing is to register for a reading course, PHIL 1995 Senior Thesis, either for the first semester alone or for both first and second semesters, with the permission of the Advisor in question. (Note that PHIL 1995 takes on a different section number according to who the Advisor is.)</p>
<p>You can register for PHIL 1995 just for one semester (followed by registering for either 3 or 4 classes in the other semester). Alternatively, you can register for PHIL 1995 for a second semester. Which you do is a matter for negotiation with your advisor, taking into account, e.g. the number of meetings, and the amount and scope of reading and writing that is done. Obviously the work-load for a Reading course needs to be about the equivalent of a normal course.</p>
<h3>Length of Thesis</h3>
<p>There's no standard length, but 40–50 pages of carefully-argued material would for many topics be a good target.</p>
<h3>Delivery</h3>
<p>Two&nbsp;copies of the Thesis are due by the Friday two weeks before the Friday on which the Reading Period begins, which will usually fall close to April 15th. They are to be handed in to the Thesis Advisor. Theses should be computer-printed, on one side only of paper; they do not need to be bound. Some people like to present them in a special folder or binder; this is fine, but not required.</p>
<h3>Examining</h3>
<p>There is usually no oral defense of the thesis. The Thesis Advisor will normally be one Reader of the thesis; there will be a second Reader too, appointed by the Concentration Advisor in consultation with the Thesis Advisor.</p>
  </div>

	



  <div class="clear-block">

<!-- Layout -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">10th Annual Mark L. Shapiro Graduate Philosophy Conference</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
<article id="node-394" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <div class="field field-type-datetime field-field-home-event-date-time">
    <div class="field-items">
            <div class="field-item odd">
                    <span class="date-display-start">November 6th, 2015 1:00 pm</span><span class="date-display-separator"> - </span><span class="date-display-end">November 7th, 2015 6:00 pm</span>        </div>
        </div>
</div>
<div class="field field-type-text field-field-home-event-location">
    <div class="field-items">
            <div class="field-item odd">
                    Pembroke Hall, 172 Meeting Street, Room 305        </div>
        </div>
</div>
<p>Brown Philosophy graduate students will host the 10th Annual Mark L.  Shapiro Graduate Philosophy Conference November 6th from 1PM to 6PM and  November 7th from 9AM to 6PM. Students from the U.S. and abroad will  convene to discuss a variety of topics. Keynote speakers will be Jamie  Dreier (Brown, November 6) and Joshua Knobe (Yale, November 7).</p>
  </div>

	



  <div class="clear-block">
    <div class="meta">

			
	    
		</div><!-- end .meta -->
	</div>

</article>
							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->

<!-- Layout -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">The 11th Annual Mark L. Shapiro Graduate Conference</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
<article id="node-554" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <div class="field field-type-datetime field-field-home-event-date-time">
    <div class="field-items">
            <div class="field-item odd">
                    <span class="date-display-start">November 4th, 2016 1:00 pm</span><span class="date-display-separator"> - </span><span class="date-display-end">November 5th, 2016 6:30 pm</span>        </div>
        </div>
</div>
<div class="field field-type-text field-field-home-event-location">
    <div class="field-items">
            <div class="field-item odd">
                    Petteruti Lounge, 75 Waterman Street        </div>
        </div>
</div>
<p>Brown Philosophy graduate students will host the 11th Annual Mark L.   Shapiro Graduate Philosophy Conference November 4th from 1PM to 6:30PM and   November 5th from 9AM to 6:30PM. Students from the U.S. and abroad will   convene to discuss a variety of topics.&nbsp;&nbsp; The keynote speakers will be <a href="https://www.brown.edu/academics/philosophy/index.php?q=bernard-reginster">Bernard Reginster</a>, Brown University and <a href="http://www.ksetiya.net/" rel="nofollow">Kieran Setiya</a>, MIT.</p>
<p>Please download the Program and Schedule <a href="https://www.brown.edu/academics/philosophy/sites/brown.edu.academics.philosophy/files/uploads/Shapiro%20Grad%20Philosophy%20Conference_%202016%20Program.pdf">here</a></p>
  </div>

	



  <div class="clear-block">
    <div class="meta">

			
	    
		</div><!-- end .meta -->
	</div>

</article>
							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">9th Annual Shapiro Graduate Student Conference in Philosophy</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
<article id="node-334" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <div class="field field-type-datetime field-field-home-event-date-time">
    <div class="field-items">
            <div class="field-item odd">
                    <span class="date-display-start">November 15th, 2014 1:00 pm</span><span class="date-display-separator"> - </span><span class="date-display-end">November 16th, 2014 6:30 pm</span>        </div>
        </div>
</div>
<div class="field field-type-text field-field-home-event-location">
    <div class="field-items">
            <div class="field-item odd">
                    Building for Environment Research and Teaching 015 (85 Waterman Street)        </div>
        </div>
</div>
<p><span>Keynote Speakers:</span></p>
<p><span>Nina Emery, Brown University&nbsp;</span></p>
<p>Shelly Kagan, Yale University</p>
  </div>

	



  <div class="clear-block">

				<div id="content">

					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Independent Studies</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>PHIL 1990 S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 13958]</span></h3>


  	An elective for students with at least six previous courses in philosophy. Section numbers vary by instructor. Please check Banner for the correct section number and CRN to use when registering for this course.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>999</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Felicia+N+Ackerman">Felicia N Ackerman</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
				
		
		
					<dt>Meeting Type</dt>
			<dd>I: Independent Study/Research</dd>
		
		


		</dl>
  </div>

							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->

					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Independent Studies</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>PHIL 1990 S02 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 13959]</span></h3>


  	An elective for students with at least six previous courses in philosophy. Section numbers vary by instructor. Please check Banner for the correct section number and CRN to use when registering for this course.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>999</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Christopher+S+Hill">Christopher S Hill</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
				
		
		
					<dt>Meeting Type</dt>
			<dd>I: Independent Study/Research</dd>
		
		


		</dl>
  </div>

							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Independent Studies</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>PHIL 1990 S03 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 13960]</span></h3>


  	An elective for students with at least six previous courses in philosophy. Section numbers vary by instructor. Please check Banner for the correct section number and CRN to use when registering for this course.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>999</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Mary+Louise+G+Gill">Mary Louise G Gill</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
				
		
		
					<dt>Meeting Type</dt>
			<dd>I: Independent Study/Research</dd>
		
		


		</dl>
  </div>

							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->

					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Independent Studies</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>PHIL 1990 S04 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 13961]</span></h3>


  	An elective for students with at least six previous courses in philosophy. Section numbers vary by instructor. Please check Banner for the correct section number and CRN to use when registering for this course.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>999</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Richard+Heck">Richard Heck</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
				
		
		
					<dt>Meeting Type</dt>
			<dd>I: Independent Study/Research</dd>
		
		


		</dl>
  </div>

							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->

					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Independent Studies</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>PHIL 1990 S05 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 13962]</span></h3>


  	An elective for students with at least six previous courses in philosophy. Section numbers vary by instructor. Please check Banner for the correct section number and CRN to use when registering for this course.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>999</dd>
		
		


		

	
				
		
		
					<dt>Meeting Type</dt>
			<dd>I: Independent Study/Research</dd>
		
		


		</dl>
  </div>

							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->

				<div id="content">

					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Independent Studies</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>PHIL 1990 S06 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 13963]</span></h3>


  	An elective for students with at least six previous courses in philosophy. Section numbers vary by instructor. Please check Banner for the correct section number and CRN to use when registering for this course.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>999</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Joshua+B+Schechter">Joshua B Schechter</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
				
		
		
					<dt>Meeting Type</dt>
			<dd>I: Independent Study/Research</dd>
		
		


		</dl>
  </div>

							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->

				<div id="content">

					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Independent Studies</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>PHIL 1990 S07 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 13964]</span></h3>


  	An elective for students with at least six previous courses in philosophy. Section numbers vary by instructor. Please check Banner for the correct section number and CRN to use when registering for this course.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>999</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Bernard+M+Reginster">Bernard M Reginster</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
				
		
		
					<dt>Meeting Type</dt>
			<dd>I: Independent Study/Research</dd>
		
		


		</dl>
  </div>

							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->

					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Independent Studies</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>PHIL 1990 S08 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 13965]</span></h3>


  	An elective for students with at least six previous courses in philosophy. Section numbers vary by instructor. Please check Banner for the correct section number and CRN to use when registering for this course.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>999</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Justin+Broackes">Justin Broackes</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
				
		
		
					<dt>Meeting Type</dt>
			<dd>I: Independent Study/Research</dd>
		
		


		</dl>
  </div>

							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->

	</div>

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Independent Studies</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>PHIL 1990 S09 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 13966]</span></h3>


  	An elective for students with at least six previous courses in philosophy. Section numbers vary by instructor. Please check Banner for the correct section number and CRN to use when registering for this course.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>999</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=James+Dreier">James Dreier</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
				
		
		
					<dt>Meeting Type</dt>
			<dd>I: Independent Study/Research</dd>
		
		


		</dl>
  </div>

							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->

	<div id="affiliations" class="clear-block block block-menu ">
	
	<h5>Affiliations</h5>	
		<div class="content"><ul class="menu"><li class="leaf first menu-ethicalinquiry"><a href="http://brown.edu/academics/philosophy/ethical-inquiry/" title="">Ethical Inquiry</a></li>

	</div>

					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Independent Studies</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>PHIL 1990 S10 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 13967]</span></h3>


  	An elective for students with at least six previous courses in philosophy. Section numbers vary by instructor. Please check Banner for the correct section number and CRN to use when registering for this course.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>999</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=David+P+Christensen">David P Christensen</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
				
		
		
					<dt>Meeting Type</dt>
			<dd>I: Independent Study/Research</dd>
		
		


		</dl>
  </div>

							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->

						</ul>
					</div>
				</div>

				
	
	<div id="affiliations" class="clear-block block block-menu ">
	
	<h5>Affiliations</h5>

					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Independent Studies</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>PHIL 1990 S11 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 13968]</span></h3>


  	An elective for students with at least six previous courses in philosophy. Section numbers vary by instructor. Please check Banner for the correct section number and CRN to use when registering for this course.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>999</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=David+Estlund">David Estlund</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
				
		
		
					<dt>Meeting Type</dt>
			<dd>I: Independent Study/Research</dd>
		
		


		</dl>
  </div>

							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Independent Studies</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>PHIL 1990 S12 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 13969]</span></h3>


  	An elective for students with at least six previous courses in philosophy. Section numbers vary by instructor. Please check Banner for the correct section number and CRN to use when registering for this course.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>999</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Adam+R+Pautz">Adam R Pautz</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
				
		
		
					<dt>Meeting Type</dt>
			<dd>I: Independent Study/Research</dd>
		
		


		</dl>
  </div>

							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->

					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Independent Studies</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>PHIL 1990 S13 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 13970]</span></h3>


  	An elective for students with at least six previous courses in philosophy. Section numbers vary by instructor. Please check Banner for the correct section number and CRN to use when registering for this course.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>999</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Charles+Larmore">Charles Larmore</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
				
		
		
					<dt>Meeting Type</dt>
			<dd>I: Independent Study/Research</dd>
		
		


		</dl>
  </div>

							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Independent Studies</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>PHIL 1990 S14 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 13971]</span></h3>


  	An elective for students with at least six previous courses in philosophy. Section numbers vary by instructor. Please check Banner for the correct section number and CRN to use when registering for this course.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>999</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Nomy+Arpaly">Nomy Arpaly</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
				
		
		
					<dt>Meeting Type</dt>
			<dd>I: Independent Study/Research</dd>
		
		


		</dl>
  </div>

							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Independent Studies</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>PHIL 1990 S15 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 13972]</span></h3>


  	An elective for students with at least six previous courses in philosophy. Section numbers vary by instructor. Please check Banner for the correct section number and CRN to use when registering for this course.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>999</dd>
		
		


		

	
				
		
		
					<dt>Meeting Type</dt>
			<dd>I: Independent Study/Research</dd>
		
		


		</dl>
  </div>

							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Independent Studies</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>PHIL 1990 S16 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 13973]</span></h3>


  	An elective for students with at least six previous courses in philosophy. Section numbers vary by instructor. Please check Banner for the correct section number and CRN to use when registering for this course.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>999</dd>
		
		


		

	
				
		
		
					<dt>Meeting Type</dt>
			<dd>I: Independent Study/Research</dd>
		
		


		</dl>
  </div>

							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Independent Studies</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>PHIL 1990 S17 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 13974]</span></h3>


  	An elective for students with at least six previous courses in philosophy. Section numbers vary by instructor. Please check Banner for the correct section number and CRN to use when registering for this course.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>999</dd>
		
		


		

	
				
		
		
					<dt>Meeting Type</dt>
			<dd>I: Independent Study/Research</dd>
		
		


		</dl>
  </div>

							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Independent Studies</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>PHIL 1990 S18 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 13975]</span></h3>


  	An elective for students with at least six previous courses in philosophy. Section numbers vary by instructor. Please check Banner for the correct section number and CRN to use when registering for this course.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>999</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Paul+D+Guyer">Paul D Guyer</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
				
		
		
					<dt>Meeting Type</dt>
			<dd>I: Independent Study/Research</dd>
		
		


		</dl>
  </div>

							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Senior Thesis</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>PHIL 1995 S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 13976]</span></h3>


  	An elective for students writing a thesis. Section numbers vary by instructor. Please check Banner for the correct section number and CRN to use when registering for this course.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>999</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Felicia+N+Ackerman">Felicia N Ackerman</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
				
		
		
					<dt>Meeting Type</dt>
			<dd>I: Independent Study/Research</dd>
		
		


		</dl>
  </div>

							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->

				<div id="content">

					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Senior Thesis</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>PHIL 1995 S02 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 13977]</span></h3>


  	An elective for students writing a thesis. Section numbers vary by instructor. Please check Banner for the correct section number and CRN to use when registering for this course.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>999</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Nomy+Arpaly">Nomy Arpaly</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
				
		
		
					<dt>Meeting Type</dt>
			<dd>I: Independent Study/Research</dd>
		
		


		</dl>
  </div>

							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->

<!-- Layout -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Senior Thesis</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>PHIL 1995 S03 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 13978]</span></h3>


  	An elective for students writing a thesis. Section numbers vary by instructor. Please check Banner for the correct section number and CRN to use when registering for this course.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>999</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Justin+Broackes">Justin Broackes</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
				
		
		
					<dt>Meeting Type</dt>
			<dd>I: Independent Study/Research</dd>
		
		


		</dl>
  </div>

							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->

    </div><!-- End #wrapper -->

<!-- Layout -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Senior Thesis</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>PHIL 1995 S04 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 13979]</span></h3>


  	An elective for students writing a thesis. Section numbers vary by instructor. Please check Banner for the correct section number and CRN to use when registering for this course.
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>999</dd>
		
		


												
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=David+P+Christensen">David P Christensen</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
				
			

	
				
		
		
					<dt>Meeting Type</dt>
			<dd>I: Independent Study/Research</dd>
		
		


		</dl>
  </div>

							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->

</ul></li>
