<!-- Layout -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Consciousness</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
  <div class="content brown-course-detail">
		
  	<h3>PHIL 1520 S01 <span class="crn">[<abbr title="Course Reference Number">CRN</abbr>: 16547]</span></h3>


  	Topics will include: (i) the different features of various types of consciousness; (ii) dualist, physicalist, and representationalist theories of experience; (iii) the nature of pain and other bodily sensations; (iv) the nature of conscious thought; (v) the qualitative dimension of perception; (vi) introspection; (vii) the roles of attention and working memory in perceptual consciousness; (viii) blindsight, inattentional blindness, hemineglect, and related phenomena; (ix) the unconscious; and (x) what it is for a state of consciousness to be unified. WRIT
		
		

		<dl>
		
		
		
		
		
		



					<dt>Term</dt>
			<dd>Fall 2017</dd>
		
					<dt>Credit Hours</dt>
			<dd>1</dd>
		
					<dt>Maximum Enrollment</dt>
			<dd>50</dd>
		
					<dt>Course Attributes</dt>
						<dd>Writing - Designated Courses</dd>
			
		


																	
	<dt>Primary Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Christopher+S+Hill">Christopher S Hill</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
											
	<dt>Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Tobias+A+Fuchs">Tobias A Fuchs</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
											
	<dt>Instructor</dt>

		<dd>
		<div class="vcard">
			<div>
						<a class="url fn" href="http://directory.brown.edu/search?search_string=Taylor+C+White">Taylor C White</a>
			</div>
			
			
		</div>
	</dd>
									
			

	
					<dt>Meetings</dt>
														<dd>
						<div class="room"><a href="http://www.brown.edu/Facilities/Facilities_Management/maps/index.php?query=Salomon Center">Salomon Center</a> 202</div>
						<div class="times">13:00 - 13:50 Mon, Wed, Fri - from Sep 6, 2017 to Sep 15, 2017						</div>
						</dd>
											<dd>
						<div class="room"><a href="http://www.brown.edu/Facilities/Facilities_Management/maps/index.php?query=Bio Med Center">Bio Med Center</a> B13</div>
						<div class="times">13:00 - 13:50 Mon, Wed, Fri - from Sep 18, 2017 to Dec 21, 2017						</div>
						</dd>
												
		
		
		
					<dt>Exam Group Code</dt>
			<dd>06</dd>
		


		</dl>
  </div>

							</div>

	<div id="block-block-4" class="clear-block block block-block ">
	
		
		<div class="content"><p><img src="http://www.brown.edu/web/images/philosophy-NewSeminar-room.jpg" /></p>
<p><strong>Department Chair</strong><br /><span><a href="mailto:paul_guyer@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Paul Guyer</a></span><a href="mailto:bernard_reginster@brown.edu" rel="nofollow"></a></p>
<p><strong>Director of Graduate Studies</strong><br /><a href="mailto:christopher_hill@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Christopher Hill</a></p>

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Affiliated Programs</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
<article id="node-192" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <ul>
<li>Other Rhode Island Departments
<ul>
<li><a href="http://www.providence.edu/PHILOSOPHY/Pages/default.aspx" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Providence College</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www2.ric.edu/philosophy/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Rhode Island College</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.uri.edu/artsci/phl/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">University of Rhode Island</a></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>Other New England Graduate Departments
<ul>
<li><a href="http://www.bc.edu/schools/cas/philosophy/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Boston College</a></li>
<li><a href="http://web.bu.edu/PHILO" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Boston University</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.fas.harvard.edu/~phildept/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Harvard University</a></li>
<li><a href="http://web.mit.edu/philos/www/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Massachusetts Institute of Technology</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.ase.tufts.edu/philosophy" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Tufts University</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.philosophy.uconn.edu/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">University of Connecticut</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.umass.edu/philosophy/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">University of Massachusetts</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.yale.edu/philos/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Yale University</a></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>Other Links of Interest
<ul>
<li><a href="http://brown.edu/academics/philosophy/ethical-inquiry/" target="_blank">Ethical Inquiry</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.brown.edu/Research/ppw/" target="_blank">Political Philosophy Workshop</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.sippatbrown.com/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Summer Immersion Program in Philosophy</a> at Brown University</li>
<li><a href="http://www.apaonline.org/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">American Philosophical Association</a></li>
<li>Keith DeRose's&nbsp;<a href="http://pantheon.yale.edu/~kd47/depts.htm" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">List of Philosophy Departments</a></li>
<li><a href="http://philpapers.org/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Online Papers in Philosophy</a></li>
<li><a href="http://philevents.org/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Philosophy Events</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.apaonline.org/?page=pj_jfp" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">PhilJobs</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.philosophicalgourmet.com/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Philosophical Gourmet Report</a><span>&nbsp;(and&nbsp;</span><a href="rgheck.frege.org/philosophy/aboutpgr.php." target="_blank" rel="nofollow">criticism thereof</a><span>)</span></li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
  </div>

	



  <div class="clear-block">
    <div class="meta">

	</div>

</article>

			<section id="banner" class="marginator sub-banner" style="background-image:url(/academics/philosophy/sites/brown.edu.academics.philosophy/files/ursa_minor_simple_banner_image.jpg); height:278px;">

<!-- Layout -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Courses for Fall 2017</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								<div class="content">



		<div class="course-section" id="PHIL">
			
				<ul class="course-list">
										<li id="PHIL0030">
					<h4>Skepticism and Knowledge</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">What is knowledge?  What is the extent and basis of one's knowledge about physical objects, other people, oneself, the future, morality, and religion? WRIT </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/philosophy/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=15422">PHIL 0030 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Ackerman</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="PHIL0050">
					<h4>Aesthetics: Art and Morality</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">From Plato to the present, the power of the arts to trigger powerful emotions has been seen by some thinkers as a threat to morality, by others as a vital support.  This debate raises such issues as whether aesthetic experience is a distinctive kind of experience and whether the creation and reception of art are autonomous activities free from the constraints of morality and politics.  Beyond Plato, authors to be read will include such figures as Hume, Mendelssohn, Rousseau, Kant, Schiller, Hegel, Schopenhauer, Ruskin, Tolstoy, Collingwood, Stanley Cavell, Martha Nussbaum, Alexander Nehamas, and others. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/philosophy/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=16546">PHIL 0050 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Guyer</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="PHIL0260">
					<h4>Philosophy of Social Science</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">This is a general introduction to the philosophy of social science. Social science brings with it certain specific problems and modes of explanation. This course is designed to introduce students to some of the issues surrounding social science. What sorts of problems and phenomena are social scientists concerned with explaining? How are they different from the problems tackled by natural scientists? Is there a mode of explanation distinctive of social science? What sorts of theoretical tools do social scientists use? We'll consider all these questions, and more. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/philosophy/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=17508">PHIL 0260 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Sankaran</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="PHIL0300G">
					<h4>Introduction to the Philosophy of Wittgenstein </h4>
					<div class="course-overview">This course examines Wittgenstein’s two groundbreaking works, the Tractatus Logico-Philosophicus (1921) and the Philosophical Investigations (1953), both of which reshaped 20th-century thought. What are the limits of language? What is the nature of philosophy? Can there be such a thing as a private language? Wittgenstein addresses these and other questions in both works. His answers are at times cryptic, such as when he says “The limits of language mean the limits of my world”. The primary goal of this course is to come to grips with the main claims of both works and the development of Wittgenstein’s thought. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/philosophy/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=17566">PHIL 0300G S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Moore</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="PHIL0350">
					<h4>Ancient Philosophy</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">This course will introduce students to the major concerns of Greek philosophy, and how they are addressed by the Presocratics, Plato, Aristotle, and the Stoics. We will have two related ends: historical and critical. On the one hand, we will get clear so far as we are able what it is that these thinkers thought; on the other, it is important to evaluate their arguments. This course will emphasize the identification of the problems and the solutions to them that seemed pressing to these thinkers, especially if such problems seem alien to us. WRIT </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/philosophy/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=15454">PHIL 0350 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Laidley</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="PHIL0540">
					<h4>Logic</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">An introduction to perhaps the most fundamental tool of rational thought: deductive logic. Course begins with basic sentential logic, then moves on to deduction, quantification, and predication. Argumentation and reasoning may also be addressed at times. No previous experience with logic or philosophy is required. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/philosophy/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=15455">PHIL 0540 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Heck</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="PHIL0850">
					<h4>Introduction to the Philosophy of Language</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">Discussion of the nature of linguistic meaning and other topics, such as vagueness; metaphor; and language, thought, and culture. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/philosophy/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=15432">PHIL 0850 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Bjurman Pautz</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="PHIL0990F">
					<h4>Perception</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">Begins with a reading of some classic works, and then moves on to contemporary work. Topics include: naive realist versus representational theories of sensory experience, the possibility that sensory experience is massively illusory (so that we already occupy a kind of “virtual reality”), the role of the brain in shaping sensory experience, and the alleged foundational role of sensory experience in knowledge. The focus will be on vision but we will also discuss other sense-modalities </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/philosophy/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=15456">PHIL 0990F S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Pautz</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="PHIL0990T">
					<h4>Paradox and Infinity</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">This course will focus on several important paradoxes that arise within philosophy and mathematics. We will use these paradoxes to investigate central issues in metaphysics, the philosophy of language, decision theory, physics, mathematics, and logic. Among the paradoxes we will discuss are Zeno's paradoxes of space, time, and motion; the paradoxes of set theory; the paradoxes of truth and reference; the sorites paradox; and paradoxes of rational action and rational belief. Enrollment limited to 20. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/philosophy/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=16400">PHIL 0990T S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Schechter</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="PHIL0991L">
					<h4>Scepticism, Ancient and Modern: Sextus, Descartes, Hume</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">Ancient Sceptics had a great series of arguments for undermining claims to knowledge and (some say) belief. (Honey tastes sweet to some, but bitter to people with a fever. 'Since everything is relative, we shall suspend judgement as to how things are independently'. And many more.) But, some say, it was only with Descartes that philosophers put in question the very existence of an independent world. We shall explore what kind of life the life of a sceptic may be; what kinds of fragmentation of the world may (or may not) result; and some differences between older and newer forms of scepticism. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/philosophy/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=15620">PHIL 0991L S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Broackes</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="PHIL1400">
					<h4>Ethics in the Novel</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">Consideration of novels in terms of their treatment of such philosophical themes as death, courage, faith, betrayal, responsibility to others, and mercy. Focuses on themes in moral philosophy rather than themes in social and political philosophy. The course deals with contemporary American novels and also with Malory. No pre-requisites. WRIT </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/philosophy/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=15425">PHIL 1400 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Ackerman</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="PHIL1520">
					<h4>Consciousness</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">Topics will include: (i) the different features of various types of consciousness; (ii) dualist, physicalist, and representationalist theories of experience; (iii) the nature of pain and other bodily sensations; (iv) the nature of conscious thought; (v) the qualitative dimension of perception; (vi) introspection; (vii) the roles of attention and working memory in perceptual consciousness; (viii) blindsight, inattentional blindness, hemineglect, and related phenomena; (ix) the unconscious; and (x) what it is for a state of consciousness to be unified. WRIT </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/philosophy/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=16547">PHIL 1520 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Hill</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="PHIL1590">
					<h4>Philosophy of Science</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">Some very general, basic questions concerning science.  Can evidence justify belief in theories which go beyond the evidence?  What is the nature of good scientific reasoning?  Is there a single scientific method? What is a scientific explanation?  Does science reveal truths about unobservable reality, or merely tell us about parts of the world we can measure directly? WRIT </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/philosophy/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=15511">PHIL 1590 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Christensen</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="PHIL1650">
					<h4>Moral Theories</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">A systematic examination of the main alternative normative moral theories: consequentialism; moral rights; moral duties; moral virtues. Focuses on the principal issues in the formulation of the different theories, on the main points of conflict between them, and on the critical evaluation of each. Readings are drawn mainly from contemporary work in moral philosophy. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/philosophy/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=15426">PHIL 1650 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Arpaly</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="PHIL1750">
					<h4>Epistemology</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">We’ll concentrate on several issues involving knowledge and rational belief:  What is knowledge, and how does it relate to rational or justified belief?  Does a person’s knowing something depend on non-evidential factors such as the practical importance of the person’s being correct?  Does the justification of a person’s belief depend just on facts internal to the person—or might it depend on her environment?  And what can we learn from thinking about the skeptical position which claims that we’re not justified in believing even the most ordinary things about the world around us? WRIT </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/philosophy/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=15510">PHIL 1750 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Christensen</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="PHIL1990">
					<h4>Independent Studies</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">An elective for students with at least six previous courses in philosophy. Section numbers vary by instructor. Please check Banner for the correct section number and CRN to use when registering for this course. </div>

												<div class="section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/philosophy/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=13989">PHIL 1995 S14</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Reginster</dd>
																								<dt>Schedule Code</dt><dd>I: Independent Study/Research</dd>
															</dl>
						</div>
						
														
																		
												<div class="section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/philosophy/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=13990">PHIL 1995 S15</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Schechter</dd>
																								<dt>Schedule Code</dt><dd>I: Independent Study/Research</dd>
															</dl>
						</div>
						
														
																										</div>
												</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="PHIL2020P">
					<h4>Color and its Place in Nature</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">Focuses on the nature and status of color, an instance of the ancient puzzle of appearance vs. reality. We will begin by examining contemporary realist views of color (Armstrong, Byrne and Hilbert, Tye). Then we will take a look at irrealist approaches (Chalmers, Pautz). Finally we will look at “relativist views” (Jonathan Cohen, Jack Spencer). Although the focus will be on color, we will also sometimes discuss other sensible properties (audible qualities, olfactory qualities, etc.) </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/philosophy/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=15622">PHIL 2020P S01</a></h5>
															<div class="section-text">This course is held on MIT's campus in Boston, MA.  Building 32, room D831.</div>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Pautz</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="PHIL2030A">
					<h4>Moral Psychology</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">This seminar will examine in depth some problems associated with morality, rationality, and the human psyche. Possible topics: acting for reasons, moral responsibility,  practical reasoning, moral character, love, modesty, being too good, moral luck, desire, weakness of will. Undergraduates require instructor permission to enroll. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/philosophy/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=15844">PHIL 2030A S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Arpaly</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="PHIL2150I">
					<h4>Plato's Theaetetus</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">In this seminar, we will discuss Plato's Theaetetus, his investigation of knowledge, and associated topics, including relativism, perception, true and false judgment, and accounts, with a view to understanding how Plato distinguishes knowledge from true belief. Open to graduate students only; others may enroll with instructor permission. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/philosophy/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=15846">PHIL 2150I S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Gill</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="PHIL2200">
					<h4>Graduate Proseminar</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">Will cover classics of philosophy from the end of the 19th century to the end of the 20th; including ethics as well as metaphysics, epistemology and philosophy of language. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/philosophy/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=15436">PHIL 2200 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Broackes</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="PHIL2800">
					<h4>Dissertation Workshop</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">No description available.  Course for graduate students during their 4th year or above. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/philosophy/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=15457">PHIL 2800 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Schechter</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="PHIL2970">
					<h4>Thesis Preparation</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">For graduate students who have met the tuition requirement and are paying the registration fee to continue active enrollment while preparing for a preliminary examination. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/philosophy/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=15015">PHIL 2970 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																								<dt>Schedule Code</dt><dd>E: Grad Enrollment Fee/Dist Prep</dd>
															</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="PHIL2980">
					<h4>Research in Philosophy</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">Section numbers vary by instructor. Please check Banner for the correct section number and CRN to use when registering for this course. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/philosophy/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=13991">PHIL 2980 S01</a></h5>

																								<dt>Schedule Code</dt><dd>I: Independent Study/Research</dd>
															</dl>
						</div>

They include:<br>
<b>Classics</b><br>
CLAS 1140 Classical Philosophy of India<br> </div>

<script type="text/javascript">
	// @todo: make show/hide link dynamically generated
	$(document).ready(function(){
	
		$(".course-list .additional-sections").hide();

		// add additional sections toggle link
		$(".course-list .additional-sections").each(function(i,el){
			var numSections = $(".section", $(this)).length;
			numSections = (numSections == 1) ? numSections + " additional section" : numSections + " additional sections";
			var anchor = $(this).parents("li").attr('id');
			$(this).after('<span class="section-count">[<a href="#' + anchor + '">Show ' + numSections + '</a>]</span>');
		});

		// now add the show/hide event listeners		
		$(".section-count").each(function(i,el){
			$("a", this).bind("click keypress", function(){
				$(".additional-sections", $(this).parents("li")).slideToggle("fast");
				window.location.hash = $(this).attr("href");
				if($(this).html().match(/Show/)) {
					$(this).html($(this).html().replace("Show", "Hide"));
				} else if($(this).html().match(/Hide/)) {
					$(this).html($(this).html().replace("Hide", "Show"));
				}
				this.text(($('#toggle').text() == 'Show more') ? 'Show less' : 'Show more');
				return false;
			});
		});
		
		if (window.location.hash) {
			var hash = window.location.hash;
			if(hash.match(/#[0-9]{4}/)) {
				$(hash +  " .additional-sections").slideDown("fast");
				$(hash +  " a[href='"+hash+"']").html($(hash +  " a[href='"+hash+"']").html().replace("Show", "Hide"));
			}
		}

	});
</script>
							</div>

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Courses in Diversity and Inclusion</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
<article id="node-594" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <p>The Philosophy Department has adopted new designations aiming to identify courses that are either relevant to issues of diversity and inclusion, or focused on them. Courses relevant to issues of diversity and inclusion (designated as RDI) are on problems, theories, or ideas that play an important role in framing any inquiry on the topics of diversity and inclusion. Courses focused on issues of diversity and inclusion (designated as FDI) are on problems, theories, or ideas about diversity and inclusion.<span>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p><span><br /></span></p>
<h3><strong>Courses Relevant to Issues of Diversity and Inclusion (RDI)</strong></h3>
<ul>
<li><strong>Philosophy of Economics - Fall 2016</strong></li>
</ul>
<p style="padding-left:30px">In this course, students will investigate the historical and contemporary overlap between philosophy and economics, from the writings of Adam Smith and Karl Marx to recent works in philosophical and economic theory. We will consider the following questions: Are economists committed to a particular theory of ethics or well-being? How should economists and philosophers understand the welfare of individuals? What is the link between free markets and important conceptions of individual freedom? How might moral and political philosophy benefit from economic analysis? How might philosophy inform or enrich economic analysis? Finally, how can economic analysis and philosophy together inform public policy?<br /><strong>PHIL 0580 S01</strong></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px"><em>Primary Instructor</em><br /><em>Preiss</em><span>&nbsp;</span></p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Marxism - Spring 2017<br /></strong></li>
</ul>
<p style="padding-left:30px">In the  first part of the course, we will examine Marx's economic, political,  and philosophical writings, focusing on his analysis of capitalism, his  critique of liberal democracy, and his theory of history. Then in the  second part, we will look at some recent attempts to renew and extend  the Marxist tradition. WRIT<br /><strong>PHIL 0400 S01</strong></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px"><em>Primary Instructor </em><br /><em> Larmore</em></p>
<ul>
<li><strong>The Philosophy of G. A. Cohen - Spring 2017<br /></strong></li>
</ul>
<p style="padding-left:30px">G. A. Cohen, who died in 2009, produced one of the most important bodies of work in political philosophy in recent decades. In this graduate seminar, we will study writings spanning the whole of Cohen's career, from his early work in "analytical Marxism" (which he partly invented), through his influential critique of libertarianism (left and right) and of the idea of self-ownership, to finally his criticisms of Rawls' theory of justice and his last, seminal work, Rescuing Justice and Equality (2008).<span>&nbsp;</span><br /><strong>PHIL 2000 S01</strong></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px"><em>Primary Instructors </em><br /><em> Larmore &amp; Estlund</em></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px"><em><br /></em></p>
<h3><span>Courses Focused on Issues of Diversity and Inclusion (FDI)<br /></span></h3>
<ul>
<li><strong>What is Free Speech? - Fall 2016</strong></li>
</ul>
<p style="padding-left:30px">Freedom of speech is a challenging  and controversial ideal. Legal questions are central, but the issues  range into moral and political philosophy as well. We will study John  Stuart Mill's influential 19th century treatment of the idea, and then  concentrate mostly on discussions within the last fifty years, including  much that is on the cutting edge of current thinking about freedom of  speech. Topics will vary, including such things as: political speech,  art and offense, pornography, hate speech, protest, copyright, internet  and new media, and campaign finance laws. WRIT<br /><strong>PHIL 0550 S01</strong></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px"><em>Primary Instructor</em><br /><em>Estlund</em></p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Global Justice - Spring 2017<br /></strong></li>
</ul>
<p style="padding-left:30px">Is it unjust that people in some countries have less wealth, worse health, etc., than those in other countries? Does this depend on whether the better off countries partly caused the disparity? Does it depend on whether the worse off are poor, or is it enough that they are relatively worse off? If there are global injustices, what obligations are there, and on whom do they fall, to remedy them? We will study (mostly) recent philosophical work on such questions, including attention to special contexts such as immigration, climate change, poverty, colonialism, secession, intervention, and war.<br /><strong>PHIL 0390 SO1</strong></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px"><span><em>Primary Instructor</em></span><br /><em>Estlund</em></p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Philosophy of Language: Slurs and Hate Speech - Fall 2016</strong></li>
</ul>
<p style="padding-left:30px">We will read some of the recent literature on slurs and hate speech, looking for connections between them. Students not graduate students in philosophy must have had a prior course in philosophy of language.<br /><strong>PHIL 2120K S01</strong></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px"><em>Primary Instructor<br />Hec<span>k</span></em></p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Bioethics Through Fiction - Spring 2017<br /></strong></li>
</ul>
<p style="padding-left:30px">This course uses fiction as a vehicle for philosophical discussions of disability, illness, and death. Topics include the following: What is disability? What is illness? What do healthy people owe sick, disabled, or dying people, and vice versa? Should we fear death? Should we prolong the lives of the terminally ill? Should we support research aimed at greatly extending the human lifespan? How can fiction enrich philosophical discussions of such questions? Readings include novels and short stories as well as writings by philosophers and bioethicists. In order to include students with varied backgrounds, this course is open to all Brown students and has no prerequisites.<br /><strong>PHIL 2160F S01</strong></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px"><em>Primary Instructor<br />Ackerman<span>&nbsp;</span></em></p>
  </div>

	



  <div class="clear-block">
    <div class="meta">

			
	    
		</div><!-- end .meta -->
	</div>

</article>

    </div><!-- End #wrapper -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Graduate</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
<article id="node-13" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <h2>Brown University Ph.D. Program in Philosophy</h2>
<p>Brown University Ph. D. program in Philosophy is designed to provide strong support for students’ research. After devoting two years to coursework, students begin their research in the third year by conducting literature reviews under the supervision of faculty members, and by enrolling in a seminar that is intended to promote work aimed at publication. These special courses help students to identify dissertation topics. Dissertation work begins in earnest in the fourth year. In that year and in succeeding years, students enroll every semester in a special seminar, the dissertation workshop, in which they present their research and receive feedback from faculty and peers. During this time they also work closely with dissertation advisers other members of their dissertation committees.</p>
<p><span>Financial support is guaranteed for the first five years of study, and also for the first four summers. It is not guaranteed for the sixth year, but in almost all cases thus far, applications for sixth year support have been successful. In the first year, students focus exclusively on course work. Teaching responsibilities begin in the second year, continue through the fourth year, and return in the sixth year. In the fifth year, however, students set teaching aside so they can concentrate on dissertation research. In this year, they may, if they like, spend periods of time at other universities, interacting with faculty and students who share their interests. Teaching responsibilities generally take the form of work as assistants in courses run by faculty, but in the fourth and sixth years, students may apply to be teaching fellows, in which case they have full responsibility for undergraduate courses. There are also opportunities for summer teaching.</span></p>
<p><span>The Department has several endowed funds, designed to support the development of graduate students and generally to improve the intellectual environment of the graduate program. The Graduate Professional Development Fund is used exclusively to promote graduate scholarship. Among other things, it provides support for giving talks at conferences and for travel to take courses at other institutions. The Mark Shapiro Fund supports an annual conference that is run entirely by graduate students. This fund also supports a bi-annual academic conference in a specific topic and a lecture series. The Royce Lectureship Fund supports a prestigious lecture series in philosophy of mind, and our department sponsors a further lecture series in collaboration with Blackwell Publishing. Finally, the Chisholm Fund currently supports a bi-annual Distinguished Visitor series, which brings to our department a distinguished philosopher for one semester. The department is also home to independently funded academic programs that sponsor multiple activities, such as lectures, workshops, and conferences in specific areas of philosophy, including the <em><a href="http://brown.edu/academics/philosophy/ethical-inquiry/" target="_blank">Program for Ethical Inquiry</a></em> and the <em><a href="http://www.brown.edu/Research/ppw/" target="_blank">Political Philosophy Workshop</a></em>.</span></p>
<p>&nbsp;<span>In addition to these departmental funds, the Brown Graduate School also makes substantial awards in support of travel by graduate students. Moreover, the Open Masters Program allows students to apply to pursue an MA degree in another discipline while pursuing a Ph. D. in Philosophy. Students admitted in this program automatically receive an additional year of financial support to complete their MA degree. Students may also apply for extra support from the University’s <em><a href="http://www.brown.edu/academics/humanities/" target="_blank">Cogut Humanities Center</a></em>. Finally, they can receive substantial assistance with teaching at the <em><a href="http://www.brown.edu/about/administration/sheridan-center/" target="_blank">Sheridan Center for Teaching and Learning. &nbsp;&nbsp;</a></em></span></p>
<p><a href="http://www.stg.brown.edu/projects/gradschool/admission.html" target="_blank">Apply Online</a></p>
<p>The Department offers admission in the fall only for its Ph.D. program. (Please note that there is no separate M.A. program in philosophy.<sup>1</sup>) Application may be made&nbsp;<a href="http://www.stg.brown.edu/projects/gradschool/admission.html" target="_blank">online</a>. Applicants must submit official transcripts, three letters of recommendation, official GRE scores (no advanced subject test is required), and a sample of philosophical writing. The application deadline is 2 January.</p>
<p>The preliminary requirements for the Ph.D. are satisfied by demonstrating competence in logic, philosophy of science, language, and mind, ethics, epistemology, metaphysics, and history of philosophy. This may be done either by passing prescribed courses with a quality grade or through satisfactory completion of an individually tailored major-minors program, planned in consultation with the Director of Graduate Studies and submitted to the department for approval.</p>
<p>Within seven semesters of full-time or equivalent residency at Brown, the student must gain admission to Ph.D. candidacy. Admission to candidacy is granted after satisfaction of the preliminary evaluation and distribution requirements and upon approval of a dissertation prospectus by a dissertation committee. An oral defense of the dissertation is required once it is completed.</p>
<p>Information about graduate studies in philosophy at Brown University is available in the department's<a href="https://www.brown.edu/academics/philosophy/sites/brown.edu.academics.philosophy/files/uploads/Graduate%20Handbook%20%282017%20version%29.pdf" target="_blank"> Graduate Student Handbook</a>.</p>
<p>Inquiries regarding&nbsp;<strong>graduate admissions</strong>&nbsp;should be directed to the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.brown.edu/academics/gradschool/" target="_blank">Graduate School</a>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<em>not</em>&nbsp;to the Director of Graduate Studies. The Director of Graduate Studies is responsible only for the Graduate Program, and plays no role in the admissions process.</p>
<hr />
<div class="footnote">
<p><sup>1</sup>This is not to say that the department does not offer a Master of Arts degree. Any student who has completed the preliminary requirements for the Ph.D. is eligible to be awarded an M.A. It is sometimes taken as a terminal degree by those who decide, for whatever reason, not to complete the Ph.D., but who have completed the preliminary requirements. And it is sometimes taken as a non-terminal degree by students who do intend to complete the Ph.D. but who would just like to receive it. The degree may also be awarded to Brown undergraduates admitted to the A.B./A.M. program.&nbsp;</p>
</div>
<fieldset class="fieldgroup group-related-files"><legend>Related Files</legend><div class="field field-type-filefield field-field-related-files">

            <div class="field-item odd">
                    <div class="filefield-file"><img class="filefield-icon field-icon-application-pdf"  alt="application/pdf icon" src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/philosophy/sites/all/modules/filefield/icons/application-pdf.png" /><a href="https://www.brown.edu/academics/philosophy/sites/brown.edu.academics.philosophy/files/uploads/Graduate%20Handbook%20%282017%20version%29.pdf" type="application/pdf; length=154975">Graduate Handbook (2017 version).pdf</a></div>        </div>
              <div class="field-item even">
                    <div class="filefield-file"><img class="filefield-icon field-icon-application-pdf"  alt="application/pdf icon" src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/philosophy/sites/all/modules/filefield/icons/application-pdf.png" /><a href="https://www.brown.edu/academics/philosophy/sites/brown.edu.academics.philosophy/files/uploads/PofM_Program_2017_8.5X11.pdf" type="application/pdf; length=1647247">PofM_Program_2017_8.5X11.pdf</a></div>        </div>

</fieldset>
  </div>

				<div id="content">

					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Graduate Students</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
<article id="node-197" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <h2>Graduate Students</h2>

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Graduate Students</h1>

<article id="node-197" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <h2>Graduate Students</h2>
<p><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/philosophy/sites/brown.edu.academics.philosophy/files/images/Barnett.jpg" alt="Zach Barnett" title="Zach Barnett"  class="image image-_original " width="100" height="125" /><span class="caption"><strong>Zach Barnett</strong></span></span><a href="mailto:Zachary_Barnett@brown.edu" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Zachary_Barnett@brown.edu</a> <br /><a href="https://sites.google.com/view/zachbarnett" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Visit Zach on the web</a></p>
<p><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/philosophy/sites/brown.edu.academics.philosophy/files/images/Brinkerhoff_0.thumbnail.jpg" alt="Anna Brinkerhoff" title="Anna Brinkerhoff"  class="image image-thumbnail " width="100" height="100" /><span class="caption"><strong>Anna Brinkerhoff</strong></span></span><a href="mailto:Anna_Brinkerhoff@brown.edu" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Anna_Brinkerhoff@brown.edu</a></p>
<p><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/philosophy/sites/brown.edu.academics.philosophy/files/images/Chalmers.jpg" alt="Harry Chalmers" title="Harry Chalmers"  class="image image-_original " width="100" height="100" /><span class="caption"><strong>Harry Chalmers</strong></span></span></p>
<p><a href="mailto:Harrison_Chalmers@brown.edu" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Harrison_Chalmers@brown.edu</a></p>
<p><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/philosophy/sites/brown.edu.academics.philosophy/files/images/Mark.thumbnail.jpeg" alt="Mark Christman" title="Mark Christman"  class="image image-thumbnail " width="100" height="100" /><span class="caption"><strong>Mark Christman</strong></span></span></p>
<p><a href="mailto:mark_christman@brown.edu" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Mark_Christman@brown.edu</a></p>
<p><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/philosophy/sites/brown.edu.academics.philosophy/files/images/C. Damstra Brown Philosophy Photo_0.thumbnail.jpg" alt="Conrad Damstra" title="Conrad Damstra"  class="image image-thumbnail " width="100" height="100" /><span class="caption"><strong>Conrad Damstra</strong></span></span></p>

<p><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/philosophy/sites/brown.edu.academics.philosophy/files/images/Picture1.thumbnail.jpg" alt="Arianna Falbo" title="Arianna Falbo"  class="image image-thumbnail " width="100" height="100" /><span class="caption"><strong>Arianna Falbo</strong></span></span></p>

<p><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/philosophy/sites/brown.edu.academics.philosophy/files/images/Larry.thumbnail.jpeg" alt="Larry Kenny" title="Larry Kenny"  class="image image-thumbnail " width="100" height="100" /><span class="caption"><strong>Larry Kenny</strong></span></span></p>

<p><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/philosophy/sites/brown.edu.academics.philosophy/files/images/Laidley_0.jpg" alt="Iain Laidley" title="Iain Laidley"  class="image image-thumbnail " width="100" height="100" /><span class="caption"><strong>Iain Laidley</strong></span></span></p>

<p><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/philosophy/sites/brown.edu.academics.philosophy/files/images/Leadon.jpg" alt="Rachel Leadon" title="Rachel Leadon"  class="image image-_original " width="100" height="100" /><span class="caption"><strong>Rachel Leadon</strong></span></span></p>
<p><a href="mailto:Rachel_Leadon@brown.edu" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Rachel_Leadon@brown.edu</a></p>
<p><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/philosophy/sites/brown.edu.academics.philosophy/files/images/Marxen.jpg" alt="Chad Marxen" title="Chad Marxen"  class="image image-_original " width="100" height="100" /><span class="caption"><strong>Chad Marxen</strong></span></span></p>

<!-- Layout -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">The Twelfth Annual Mark L. Shapiro Graduate Philosophy Conference</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
<article id="node-762" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <div class="field field-type-datetime field-field-home-event-date-time">
    <div class="field-items">
            <div class="field-item odd">
                    <span class="date-display-start">November 17th, 2017 1:00 pm</span><span class="date-display-separator"> - </span><span class="date-display-end">November 18th, 2017 6:30 pm</span>        </div>
        </div>
</div>
<div class="field field-type-text field-field-home-event-location">
    <div class="field-items">
            <div class="field-item odd">
                    Pembroke Hall, Room 305        </div>
        </div>
</div>
<p>Brown Philosophy graduate students will host the 12th Annual Mark L.    Shapiro Graduate Philosophy Conference November 17th from 1PM to 6:30PM  and   November 18th from 9AM to 6:30PM in Pembroke Hall, Room 305. Students from the U.S. and abroad  will   convene to discuss a variety of topics.&nbsp; The keynote speakers will include <a href="http://www.philosophy.utoronto.ca/directory/imogen-dickie/" rel="nofollow">Imogen Dickie</a>, University of Toronto and a member of our faculty.</p>
  </div>

	



  <div class="clear-block">
    <div class="meta">

			
	    
		</div><!-- end .meta -->
	</div>

</article>
							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->

					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Undergraduate</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
<article id="node-12" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <h2><span>Description</span></h2>
<p>The undergraduate concentration in philosophy offers courses covering all of the main areas of the discipline, from epistemology and metaphysics to philosophy of religion, philosophy of literature, and feminist philosophy. It also offers courses covering all the various periods in the  history of philosophy. Concentrators can expect to strengthen their  knowledge of and skills in ancient philosophy, early modern philosophy,  logic, epistemology, metaphysics and philosophy of value. While the concentration provides a strong general education in philosophy, concentrators are required to identify  an area of specialization.</p>
<p>Students with questions about the concentration should contact the Director of Undergraduate Studies, <a href="mailto:justin_broackes@brown.edu" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Justin Broackes</a>.</p>
<h2>Student Goals</h2>
<p>Students in philosophy will:</p>
<ul>
<li>Learn to think analytically and creatively about philosophical texts and issues</li>
<li>Understand the work of major figures in the history of philosophy, including Plato, Aristotle, Descartes and Kant</li>
<li>Become familiar with arguments and approaches in metaphysics or  epistemology, and a selection of other areas of philosophy, such as  philosophy of mind and philosophy of language; as well as topics in  ethics and political philosophy</li>
<li>Know how to carry out logical proofs and derivations within a formal system</li>
<li>Produce a significant body of written work</li>
</ul>
<h2>Concentration Requirements</h2>
<p>New concentration requirements became effective in January 2013.  Students who declared their concentration prior to that date are still  subject to the old requirements, which can be found in the <a href="http://bulletin.brown.edu/the-college/concentrations/phil/" target="_blank">University Bulletin</a>.</p>
<p>The current requirement is ten courses total of which no more than  one may be below Phil 0350, and at least three of which must be at or  above Phil 0990.</p>
<h3>Distribution Requirements</h3>
<p>Each philosophy concentrator must take:</p>
<ul>
<li>One course in Ancient Philosophy<br />e.g. Phil 0350 Ancient Philosophy; Phil 1250 Aristotle	; Phil 1260 Plato; Phil 1310 Myth and the Origins of Science</li>
<li>One course in Early Modern Philosophy<br />e.g. Phil 0360 Early Modern Philosophy; Phil 1700 British  Empiricists; Phil 1710 17th Century Continental Rationalism; Phil 1720 Kant: The Critique of Pure Reason</li>
<li>One course in Epistemology or Metaphysics<br />e.g. Phil 1660 Metaphysics; Phil 1750 Epistemology; Phil 1760 Philosophy of Language; Phil 1765 Sense and Reference; Phil 1770 Philosophy of Mind</li>
<li>One course in Ethics or Political Philosophy<br />e.g. Phil 0500 Moral Philosophy; Phil 0560 Political Philosophy;  Phil 1640 The Nature of Morality; Phil 1650 &nbsp;Moral Theories</li>
<li>One course in Logic<br />e.g. Phil 0540 Logic; Phil 1630 Deductive Logic; Phil 1880 Advanced Deductive Logic; Phil 1885 Incompleteness</li>
<li>One seminar: &nbsp;A course from the Phil 0990 series or any seminar at the 2000-level, which may be counted for one of the other requirements.</li>
</ul>
<h3>Specialization</h3>
<p>Students are asked to choose a "specialization", consisting of three  related courses from a single area of philosophy, for example: logic and  language; philosophy of science; epistemology; philosophy of mind; moral  philosophy; political philosophy; ancient philosophy; and so forth. At  most one course from the specialization can also be counted for one of  the five area requirements.</p>
<p>Concentrators who aim at a general acquaintance with the discipline of philosophy may forgo a specialization and devise an appropriately balanced program of courses beyond the requirements with the approval of the DUS (Director of Undergraduate Studies).</p>
<p>No more than one course may fulfill both a general distribution requirement and a specialization requirement.</p>
<p>No more than two courses from departments other than the philosophy department may be counted among the ten courses required for the concentration; no more than one of these two outside courses may count towards the three specialization requirements.&nbsp;</p>
<p>The specialization and the courses that will fulfill it are standardly declared at some point in the course of the Junior year. &nbsp;Those making a Concentration Declaration at an earlier time (e.g. at the end of their Sophomore year) may make a provisional choice of courses which can be revised at a later date with the approval of the department's DUS (Director of Undergraduate Studies).</p>
<ul class="small">
</ul>
<h5>Capstone</h5>
<p>Each philosophy concentrator must complete a "capstone". For more information, see the page on the <a href="http://www.brown.edu/academics/philosophy/undergraduate/senior-year" target="_blank">senior year</a>.</p>
<h2>Honors</h2>
<p>Philosophy concentrators have the option of writing an <a href="http://www.brown.edu/academics/philosophy/undergraduate/thesis" target="_blank">Honor's Thesis</a>,  which is typically researched and written over the course of the entire  senior year. Interested students should consult with the concentration  advisor during the sixth semester concerning procedures and  requirements. &nbsp;Philosophy GPA must be greater than 3.5. &nbsp;(This refers to the GPA at the beginning of the senior year in all philosophy courses, and including at least six courses.)</p>
<h2>Physics and Philosophy Concentration</h2>
<p>This page describes the "standard" concentration in Philosophy. There is  also a related but separate concentration in Physics and Philosophy.  More information on that program is available from  <a href="http://brown.edu/academics/physics/undergraduate/concentrations/concentrations" target="_blank">the Physics department</a> and from  <a href="http://www.brown.edu/Administration/Registrar/Concentrations-70b.htm" target="_blank">the Registrar's office</a>.</p>
  </div>

	



  <div class="clear-block">

					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Philosophy: What and Why?</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
<article id="node-338" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <h2>What is Philosophy?</h2>
<p><span>Philosophy is the systematic and critical study of fundamental questions that arise both in everyday life and through the practice of other disciplines. Some of these questions concern the nature of </span><em>reality</em><span>: Is there an external world? What is the relationship between the physical and the mental? Does God exist? Others concern our nature as rational, purposive, and social beings: Do we act freely? Where do our moral obligations come from? How do we construct just political states? Others concern the nature and extent of our knowledge: What is it to know something rather than merely believe it? Does all of our knowledge come from sensory experience? Are there limits to our knowledge? And still others concern the foundations and implications of other disciplines: What is a scientific explanation? What sort of knowledge of the world does science provide? Do scientific theories, such as evolutionary theory, or quantum mechanics, compel us to modify our basic philosophical understanding of, and approach to, reality? What makes an object a work of art? Are aesthetic value judgments objective? And so on.</span></p>
<p>The aim in Philosophy is not to master a body of facts, so much as think clearly and sharply through any set of facts. Towards that end, philosophy students are trained to read critically, analyze and assess arguments, discern hidden assumptions, construct logically tight arguments, and express themselves clearly and precisely in both speech and writing.</p>
<p>Here are descriptions of some of the main areas of philosophy:</p>
<h3>Epistemology</h3>
<p>Epistemology studies questions about knowledge and rational belief.&nbsp; Traditional questions include the following: How can we know that the ordinary physical objects around us are real (as opposed to dreamed, or hallucinated, as in the Matrix)? &nbsp;What are the factors that determine whether a belief is rational or irrational?&nbsp; What is the difference between knowing something and just believing it?&nbsp; (Part of the answer is that you can have false beliefs, but you can only know things that are true.&nbsp; But that’s not the whole answer—after all, you might believe something true on the basis of a lucky guess, and that wouldn’t be knowledge!)&nbsp;&nbsp; Some other questions that have recently been the subject of lively debate in epistemology include: Can two people with exactly the same evidence be completely rational in holding opposite beliefs?&nbsp; Does whether I know something depend on how much practical risk I would face if I believed falsely?&nbsp; Can I rationally maintain confident beliefs about matters on which I know that others, who are seemingly every bit as intelligent, well-informed, unbiased and diligent as I am, have come to opposite conclusions?</p>
<h3>Metaphysics</h3>
<p>Metaphysics is the study of what the world is like—or (some would say) what reality consists in. Metaphysical questions can take several forms. They can be questions about what exists (questions of ontology); they can be questions what is fundamental (as opposed to derivative); and they can be questions about what is an objective feature of the world (as opposed to a mere consequence the way in which creatures like us happen to interact with that world). Questions that are central to the study of metaphysics include questions about the nature of objects, persons, time, space, causation, laws of nature, and modality. The rigorous study of these questions has often led metaphysicians to make surprising claims. Plato thought that alongside the observable, concrete world there was a realm of eternal, unchanging abstract entities like Goodness, Beauty, and Justice. Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz claimed that the world was composed of tiny indivisible souls, called monads. Even today contemporary metaphysicians have been known to doubt the existence of ordinary objects, to deny the possibility of free will, and to argue that our world is just one of a plurality of worlds.</p>
<h3>Logic</h3>
<p>Logic is the study of the validity of patterns of inference. Logic is not a branch of psychology: It does not concern how people actually reason or which kinds of reasoning they find intuitively compelling. Rather, logic concerns the question of when a claim is conclusively supported by other claims. For instance, the inference from the claims “it is raining” and “if it is raining then the streets are wet” to the claim “the streets are wet” is logically valid – the premises conclusively support the conclusion. The validity of this specific inference, and of other inferences of the same form, is tied to the nature of the concept “if … then”. More generally, the notion of logical validity is closely connected to the nature of concepts such as “and”, “or”, “not”, “if … then”, “all”, and “some”. In studying the notion of logical validity, logicians have developed symbolic languages. These enable us to state claims clearly and precisely, and to investigate the exact structure of an argument. These languages have turned out to be useful within philosophy and other disciplines, including mathematics and computer science. Some of the questions about logic studied by members of the philosophy department include: Given that logic is not an empirical science, how can we have knowledge of basic logical truths? What is the connection between logic and rationality? Can mathematics be reduced to logic? Should we revise logic to accommodate vague or imprecise language? Should we revise logic to answer the liar paradox and other paradoxes concerning truth?<span>&nbsp;</span></p>
<h3>Political Philosophy</h3>
<p>Political philosophy is the philosophical study of concepts and values associated with political matters. For one example, is there any moral obligation to do what the law says just because the law says so, and if so on what grounds? Many have said we consent to obey. Did you consent to obey the laws? Can one consent without realizing it? Are there other grounds for an obligation to obey the law? Another central question is what would count as a just distribution of all the wealth and opportunity that is made possible by living in a political community? Is inequality in wealth or income unjust? Much existing economic inequality is a result of different talents, different childhood opportunities, different gender, or just different geographical location. What might justify inequalities that are owed simply to bad luck? Some say that inequality can provide incentives to produce or innovate more, which might benefit everyone. Others say that many goods belong to individuals before the law enters in, and that people may exchange them as they please even if this results in some having more than others. So (a third question), what does it mean for something to be yours, and what makes it yours?</p>
<h3>Philosophy of Language</h3>
<p>&nbsp;<span>The Philosophy of Language is devoted to the study of questions concerned with meaning and communication. Such questions range from ones that interact closely with linguistic theory to questions that are more akin to those raised in the study of literature. Very large questions include: What is linguistic meaning? How is the meaning of linguistic performances similar to and different from the meanings of, say, gestures or signals? What is the relationship between language and thought? Is thought more fundamental than language? Or is there some sense in which only creatures that can speak can think? To what extent does the social environment affect the meaning and use of language? Other questions focus on the communicative aspect of language, such as: What is it to understand what someone else has said? What is it to assert something? How is assertion related to knowledge and belief? And how is it that we can gain knowledge from others through language? Yet other questions focus on specific features of the langauges we speak, for example: What is it a name to be a name of a particular thing? What's the relationship between the meanings of words and the meanings of sentences? Is there an important difference between literal and figurative uses of language? What is metaphor? And how does it work?</span></p>
<h3>Moral Philosophy</h3>
<p>Ethics is the study of what we ought to do and what sorts of people we<br /> ought to be. &nbsp;Ethicists theorize about what makes acts right and wrong and what<br /> makes outcomes good and bad, and also about which motivations and<br /> traits of character we should admire and cultivate. &nbsp;Some other questions that ethicists try to answer are closely related to the central ones. They include: What does it mean to act&nbsp;freely? Under what conditions are we responsible for our good and bad&nbsp;acts? Are moral claims true and false, like ordinary descriptive<br /> claims about our world, and if they are what makes them so?</p>
<h3>Aesthetics</h3>
<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; [forthcoming]</p>
<h3>History of Philosophy</h3>
<p>The History of Philosophy plays a special role in the study of philosophy. Like every other intellectual discipline, philosophy has of course a history. &nbsp;However, in the case of philosophy an understanding of its history - from its ancient and medieval beginnings through the early modern period (the 17th and 18th centuries) and into more recent times - forms a vital part of the very enterprise of philosophy, whether in metaphysics and epistemology or in ethics, aesthetics, and political philosophy. &nbsp;To study the great philosophical works of the past is to learn about the origins and presuppositions of many of the problems that occupy philosophy today. &nbsp;It is also to discover and to come to appreciate different ways of dealing with these problems, different conceptions of what the fundamental problems of philosophy are, and indeed different ways of doing philosophy altogether. &nbsp;And it is also the study of works—from Plato and Aristotle, through Kant and Mill and more recent writers—that have shaped much of Western culture far beyond academic philosophy. Many of the most creative philosophers working today have also written on various topics in the history of philosophy and have found their inspiration in great figures of the past.<span>&nbsp;</span></p>
<h2>Why Study Philosophy?</h2>
<p>This question may be understood in two ways: Why would one engage in the particular intellectual activities that constitute philosophical inquiry? And how might the study of philosophy affect my future career prospects?<span>&nbsp;</span></p>
<ul>
<li>Philosophy as intellectual activity may have a number of motivations:</li>
</ul>
<ul>
<li>Intellectual curiosity: philosophy is essentially a <em>reflective-critical inquiry</em> motivated by a sense of intellectual “wonder.” What is the world like? Why is it this way, rather than another? Who am I? Why am I here?</li>
<li>Interest in cultural and intellectual history: as a discipline, philosophy pays a great deal of attention to its history, and to the broader cultural and intellectual context in which this history unfolds.</li>
<li>Sharpening thinking skills: the study of philosophy is especially well suited to the development of a variety of intellectual skills involved in the analysis of concepts, the critique of ideas, the conduct of sound reasoning and argumentation; it is important to emphasize that philosophical inquiry also fosters intellectual creativity (developing new concepts, or new approaches to problems, identifying new problems, and so on).</li>
<li>Sharpening writing skills: the writing of philosophy is especially rigorous insofar as it demands a high level of clarity, precision, and organization.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
<li>Philosophy might affect future career prospects in a number of ways:</li>
</ul>
<ul>
<li>Some philosophy concentrators go on to graduate school to earn a PhD in philosophy. Most of those become professors of philosophy, which means that their professional lives are devoted to research and teaching in philosophy.</li>
<li>A philosophy concentration is not limiting: in fact, the skills it develops and sharpens are transferable to a wide variety of professional activities. Obvious examples include the application of reasoning and argumentation skills to the practice of law; less obvious examples include the application of analytical and critical skills to journalism, investment banking, writing, publishing, and so on; even less obvious examples include putting one’s philosophical education to work in business entrepeneurship, political and social activism, and even creative arts.</li>
</ul>
  </div>

	



  <div class="clear-block">
    <div class="meta">

	</div>

</article>

	<div class="tel"><span class="type">Phone</span> <span class="value">401-863-6346</span></div>
	<div class="tel"><span class="type">Fax</span> <span class="value">401-863-2719</span></div>
	<div><a class="email" href="mailto:philosophy_dept@brown.edu">philosophy_dept@brown.edu</a></div>

<!-- Layout -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Senior Year </h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
<article id="node-313" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <h2>Senior Year Options</h2>
<p>There are several options for a 'Capstone Experience' in philosophy.</p>
<h3>An Honors Thesis</h3>
<p>Seniors wishing to earn honors by presenting a senior honors thesis should consult their concentration advisor during their sixth semester or at the start of the seventh semester, concerning procedures and requirements. In addition to completing the usual nonhonors requirements, a student must write a thesis judged to be of honors quality by two readers and have a grade point average of over 3.5 in philosophy courses. &nbsp;(The GPA at the beginning of the senior year must be greater than 3.5, including at least six courses, of which at least five must be taken for a letter grade; and the GPA must be at least 3.5 at the end of the Senior year.) Honors theses are usually prepared over two semesters' work with an advisor. There is more information on writing an honors thesis on&nbsp;<a href="http://www.brown.edu/academics/philosophy/undergraduate/thesis" target="_blank">this page.</a></p>
<h3>A Reading Course</h3>
<p>Many professors will be happy to set up a Phil 1990 reading course for one semester with an individual student, e.g. leading to the preparation of a special large paper on a particular topic of research. One option is to set up a Reading Course to accompany a 1000-level course that you have recently taken or are taking at the same time. For example, you might take Phil 1660 Metaphysics, and also do a special reading course on Necessity or on Reduction and Supervenience. Or you might take Phil 1640, The Nature of Morality, and also do a reading course to specialize in the notion of Moral Facts. In each case the 1000-level course would provide a general overview of the topic and give you an idea of one professor's views, and then you could research further in the subject either with that same professor or with another with overlapping interests. A one-semester Reading Course may also for some people be a first step towards writing an Honors Thesis.</p>
<h3>Senior Seminars</h3>
<p><span>There are seminars in the Phil 0990 series, aimed primarily at advanced undergraduates, on varying topics each year.</span></p>
<h3>Graduate Seminars</h3>
<p>2000-level seminars are mainly aimed at graduate students, but many are able to take advanced undergraduates as well. The best preparation is usually to have done a 1000-level course with the same professor or in the same general area of philosophy.</p>
<p><span>Please feel free to talk to the Concentration Advisors about ideas and questions you might have about any of these options or to approach in office hours individual professors who might be able to help you as an advisor for a particular project.</span></p>
  </div>

	



  <div class="clear-block">
    <div class="meta">

			
	    
		</div><!-- end .meta -->
	</div>

</article>
							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->
